item.title: Automatic Benchmark Profiling through Advanced Trace Analysis
item.dc:creator: NYU Reproducibility Working Group
item.description: Benchmarking has proven to be crucial for the investigation of the behavior and performances of a system. However, the choice of relevant benchmarks still remains a challenge. To help the process of comparing and choosing among benchmarks, we propose a solution for automatic benchmark profiling. It computes unified benchmark profiles reflecting benchmarksâ€™ duration, function repartition, stability, CPU efficiency, parallelization and memory usage. It identifies the needed system information for profile computation, collects it from execution traces and produces profiles through efficient and reproducible trace analysis treatments. The paper presents the design, implementation and the evaluation of the approach. The analysis of the kernel trace follows a workflow implemented using the VisTrails tool.

item.title: SIGMOD Repeatability Effort
item.dc:creator: NYU Reproducibility Working Group
item.description: As part of this project, in collaboration with Philippe Bonnet, we are using (and extending) our infrastructure to support the SIGMOD Repeatability effort. Below are some case studies that illustrate how authors can create provenance-rich and reproducible papers, and how reviewers can both reproduce the experiments and perform workability tests: packaging an experiment on a distributed database system (link in title).

item.title: Galois Conjugates of Topological Phases
item.dc:creator: NYU Reproducibility Working Group
item.description: Professor Matthias Troyer (ETH Zurich) and his collaborators have published a number of papers whose results are fully reproducible. He is using VisTrails to both carry out the experiments and to package them for publication.

item.title: The ALPS Project Release 2.0: Open Source Software for Strongly Correlated Systems
item.dc:creator: NYU Reproducibility Working Group
item.description: Professor Matthias Troyer (ETH Zurich) and his collaborators have published a number of papers whose results are fully reproducible. He is using VisTrails to both carry out the experiments and to package them for publication.
